newsitem.title: USA: US spot resids firm on crude rally, Gulf HSFO talk.
newsitem.headline: US spot resids firm on crude rally, Gulf HSFO talk.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel oil grades firmed Tuesday on a rally in crude futures and interest in high-sulphur materials in the Gulf Coast market.
"It's strictly off the back of crude," said one Houston resid trader when asked about the factor behind today's rise.
NYMEX April crude settled up $1.14 at $22.06 a barrel on technicals and delivery disruption on the Mississippi River.
Market sources said supplies of high-sulphur grades in the Gulf were tight with producers waiting for stronger prices.
"People are holding for prices to come up. People are sitting on inventory," said one Gulf Coast dealer.

In the U.S. Gulf, three percent sulphur grade was talked up to $13.75 a barrel with offers heard as high as $14.00. Three percent paper was quoted at $14.00-20. USG one percent was pulled to $14.50, the upper end of Monday's range.
NYH HSFO were assessed higher with three percent edging up to $13.25-50. The 0.3 percent high pour grade held at $16.75.
NYH one percent physical prices climbed 25 cents to $15.75-16.00. One percent paper rose to $16.10-25 from Monday's $15.75-16.00.
Forecasts of cold weather along the East Coast this week moved swing natural gas prices higher again.
At the New York City gate, day-ahead gas prices firmed to $2.37-2.44 per million British thermal units or $15.12 a barrel equivalent from Monday's $2.29-2.34 or $14.80/bbl.
But natgas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, fell sharply to $1.90/mmBtu or 11.97/bbl from Monday's $2.00/mmBtu or $12.60/bbl equivalent.
Spot resid activity is expected to resume toward normal level as participants return from the National Petroleum Refiners Association conference in San Antonio, Texas.
